69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:59): well, shows what i know :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:01): btw, what's the plan for actually defining the requirements for things like mouse and key events, is that in dom3 events?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: as in Use Cases and Requirements?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:03): as in, the text that says "when a user presses down on a key on the keyboard, the user agent must send a keydown event that..." or whatever

227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:03): I don't know that I was that systematic about it before, since I was picking up a spec that I thought was nearly done... but I see that we would benefit from having those well-defined beforehand
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:04): would probably make sense to have that in a separate spec, but i'd imagine that e.g. for mouse events it would be the same spec that defines MouseEvent
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:04): I think that it would be best to define that in the D3E spec, and then mention that a host language can override or repurpose them for that specific case
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:04): how does that strike you?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:05): to me, it might clarify the context in which the event was "designed"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:05): seems independent of host language, since DOM3 Events presumably would work unchanged whether the Document object had any child nodes or not
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:06): doesn't really understand the concept of "host language" these days
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:06): seems somewhat anachronistic
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:06): well, I might be stretching the term a bit
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:07): I use it to mean, another spec that reuses this spec as a sort of integrated module
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:07): but I don't see that as an important point
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:08): basically, I'd expect mouse events to function pretty much uniformly across SVG, HTML, MathML, etc.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:08): are we expecting dom3 events to be reused, rather than just implemented as is?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:09): reuse in that way sounds scary; i agree that we'd want it to behave uniformly everywhere
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:09): but certain things, like the "load" event, have idiosyncratic behavior in HTML (eg)
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:09): and thus HTML woudl define that behavior as a sort of extension to D3E
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:09): well presumably we'd want that event to work the same regardless of what the root element happens to be
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:10): that said, I'm not totally committed to that, it's just the way I had been thinking about it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:10): though that would mean defining the xml parser in a more useful way than currently, i guess
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:10): isn't sure what to do about the dependencies on an xml parser spec in html5
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:10): hmmm... load works differently in HTML vs. SVG, iirc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:10): huh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:10): i thought SVG fired SVGLoad, not load
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:11): if it's a 'load' event, how does a UA know how to fire it?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:11): maybe this should indeed be handled by the dom3 events spec somehow
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:12): though really neither xhtml nor svg should be firing the 'load' event, that should just be fired by a generic "xml parsing for scripted uas" spec
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:12): http://www.w3.org/TR/SVGTiny12/interact.html#LoadEvent
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:12): hm
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:12): is that defined anywhere?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:13): (or that description all there is?)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:13): s/or/or is/
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:14): I think that's all
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:15): what do you think is missing?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:17): well there are no requirements there, for one
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:17): so nothing testable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:17): even if we pretend that the descriptive text is normative, it's also very vague, e.g.:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:17): what does "finishes loading the element" mean?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:17): what does "after" mean?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:18): is the event fired synchronously or asynchronously?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:18): what is the target of the event?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:19): what exactly are the dependent resources?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:19): does it trigger when the element is reinserted? some of the text suggests not, some suggests it is

227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:21): I understand that you prefer more precise wording, but I question whether that is strictly necessary for an implementer to create an interoperable implementation of the load event...
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:21): I think some of the questions there are not a big deal, and a reasonable reading of the text would satisfy most developers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:22): well without violating the w3c process, how will svg 1.2 tiny get to CR if the spec isn't testable?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:22): that said, that text is very old and when we write SVG Core we will be more precise
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:22): get past CR, i mean
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:23): apologises for being passive-aggressive
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:24): I don't think we're headed in a productive direction, so let's save that discussion for another time

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:24): anyway, html has taught us that if a technology gets widely deployed, this kind of detail will get locked down, de-facto if not de-jure, and if it's de-facto then it'll be mostly random
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:24): wrt mutation events, I'm getting mixed signals from Mozilla and script library folks

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:24): the mess that people complain about in html is basically all due to the people writing the specs in the past saying "I think some of the questions there are not a big deal, and a reasonable reading of the text would satisfy most developers"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:25): re mutation events; what are the options on the table?

227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:26): on the one hand, Moz has said they are fine with some of the mutation events staying as-is in the spec (which is what script librarians want), but they then say they won't implement them... I don't want to put features in D3E that Moz won't implement
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:26): well that seems like an easy choice then
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:26): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, it's been a while, so why don't I review and summarize the issues, and send them to the webapps list?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:26): that might help, yeah

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:27): to make progress on the html5 spec i don't really care what the mutation event spec says, i just need it to be precise so i know how to fiddle with the rules, basically
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:27): understood
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:27): what's your timetable

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:27): there's some things where we want them to not fire at all and some where we want them to fire in particular ways, and right now i just don't know how to do it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:27): well, html5 is supposed to be locked down and done by october
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (08:27): I can "finalize" parts of D3E in advance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:27): i expect to have most of this stuff done by end-of-q2
